pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 892, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 766, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 548, 359, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 462, 88]]<|/det|>
A student measures the volume of a cork.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
He puts some water into a measuring cylinder and then one glass ball. He puts the cork and then a second, identical glass ball into the water as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 147, 819, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 428, 412]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows the first water level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 424, 628, 443]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows the water level after one glass ball is added.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 454, 808, 472]]<|/det|>
Diagram 3 shows the water level after the cork and the second glass ball are added.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 381, 502]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the cork?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 512, 128, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 871, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an air-filled rubber toy. A child sits on the toy and its volume decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 561, 120]]<|/det|> The temperature of the air in the toy does not change. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 128, 695, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 276, 567, 294]]<|/det|> How does the air pressure in the toy change and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 707, 435]]<|/det|>
pressurereason
Adecreasesair molecules move more slowly
Bdecreasesair molecules strike the rubber less frequently
Cincreasesair molecules move more quickly
Dincreasesair molecules strike the rubber more frequently
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 462, 106, 480]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 920, 495]]<|/det|> A strip of iron and a strip of brass are firmly attached to each other along their entire length. This combination is a bimetallic strip. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 504, 660, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 551, 622]]<|/det|> This bimetallic strip is heated and it bends as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 631, 727, 732]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 742, 630, 759]]<|/det|> The bimetallic strip is now cooled and becomes straight again. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 772, 599, 789]]<|/det|> What causes the bimetallic strip to become straight again? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 800, 134, 819]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 800, 479, 819]]<|/det|> The brass contracts more than the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 134, 846]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 828, 475, 846]]<|/det|> The brass expands more than the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 855, 131, 873]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 855, 479, 873]]<|/det|> The iron contracts more than the brass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 881, 133, 899]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 881, 475, 899]]<|/det|> The iron expands more than the brass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 235, 910, 253]]<|/det|>

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 262, 915, 280]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 289, 490, 307]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 316, 581, 333]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 104, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 531, 518]]<|/det|> A laser is a source of light with a single frequency. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 512, 548]]<|/det|> Which description of this type of light is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 138, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 559, 237, 577]]<|/det|> dispersed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 586, 133, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 586, 222, 603]]<|/det|> focused <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 133, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 612, 282, 630]]<|/det|> monochromatic <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 638, 133, 656]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 638, 230, 656]]<|/det|> refracted <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 682, 106, 700]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 853, 700]]<|/det|> Visible light, X-rays and microwaves are all components of the electromagnetic spectrum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 490, 729]]<|/det|> Which statement about the waves is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 758]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 868, 757]]<|/det|> In a vacuum, microwaves travel faster than visible light and have a shorter wavelength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 133, 784]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 766, 920, 800]]<|/det|> In a vacuum, microwaves travel at the same speed as visible light and have a shorter wavelength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 807, 133, 825]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 807, 824, 825]]<|/det|> In a vacuum, X-rays travel faster than visible light and have a shorter wavelength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 833, 133, 851]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 833, 912, 851]]<|/det|> In a vacuum, X-rays travel at the same speed as visible light and have a shorter wavelength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 394, 526, 412]]<|/det|>

<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 824, 562]]<|/det|>
A positively-charged rod is held near to, but not touching, an uncharged metal sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 574, 489, 592]]<|/det|>
The sphere is briefly now connected to earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 285, 622]]<|/det|>
The rod is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 634, 611, 652]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the charge on the sphere is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 133, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 662, 880, 680]]<|/det|>
It is charged negatively because negative charges have moved from earth to the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 689, 133, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 873, 707]]<|/det|>
It is charged negatively because positive charges have moved from the sphere to earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 715, 131, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 715, 873, 733]]<|/det|>
It is charged positively because negative charges have moved from the sphere to earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 742, 133, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 742, 866, 759]]<|/det|>
It is charged positively because positive charges have moved to earth from the sphere.

emission Xemission Y
A\(\alpha \)-particles\(\beta \)-particles
